title: FacaDiffy: Inpainting unseen facade parts using diffusion models
author: Thomas Froch (Technical University of Munich), Olaf Wysocki (Technical University of Munich), Yan Xia (Technical University of Munich), Junyu Xie (University of Oxford), Benedikt Schwab (Technical University of Munich), Daniel Cremers (Technical University of Munich), Thomas H. Kolbe (Technical University of Munich), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces a novel method using deep learning approaches in computer vision, specifically diffusion models, which could inspire similar applications in audio data processing, such as audio inpainting or sound event detection.
background: The task involves completing incomplete 2D conflict maps derived from building models and laser scanning data to improve 3D reconstructions of urban environments.
contribution: FacaDiffy introduces a personalized Stable Diffusion model for inpainting to complete conflict maps, achieving a 22% increase in detection rate for 3D semantic reconstruction.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior methods for facade reconstruction lacked effective handling of occluded areas and often resulted in incomplete mappings.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon existing methods by utilizing personalized diffusion models to fill gaps and enhance accuracy of conflict maps.

key_innovation: The unique integration of deterministic ray analysis with personalized inpainting techniques allows for more effective reconstruction of urban facades from incomplete data.
real_world_impact: The method has significant implications for urban planning and construction by improving 3D model accuracy, which can be applied in simulations for solar potential and environmental analysis.
limitations: The ray analysis approach may struggle with complex or transparent structures, and the effectiveness could be sensitive to the input text prompts used in inpainting.

new_terms.conflict maps: **Conflict maps** are 2D representations indicating areas of certainty and uncertainty regarding features on building facades, used for guiding semantic reconstruction.
new_terms.Stable Diffusion: **Stable Diffusion** is a type of generative model that utilizes diffusion processes for high-fidelity image generation and can be adapted for tasks like inpainting.

open_sourcing: The code is publicly available in the corresponding GitHub repository: https://github.com/ThomasFroech/InpaintingofUnseenFacadeObjects
